slides.text: 'We need MORE units. Where can we get them? From the TENS! Take 1 ten bar and exchange it for 10 units.' Do the exchange: 1 ten bar → 10 units.
slides.mascot_explanation: Uh oh, we don't have enough little beads to take away! But don't worry, we can get more! We're going to take one of the long "ten" bars and trade it for 10 little unit beads. It's like magic – one long bar turns into lots of small ones!

slides.text: 'Now we have 12 units! Can we take 7 from 12? YES! 12 minus 7 is 5 units.' Remove 7. '5 units remain. But now we only have 3 tens instead of 4.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! Now we have 10 new unit beads plus the 2 we already had, so we have 12 units! Now can we take away 7? Yes, we can! When we take 7 away from 12, we have 5 units left. But remember, we used one of our ten bars, so we only have 3 tens left now.

slides.text: 'Tens: 3 minus 2 = 1 ten. Hundreds: 5 minus 3 = 2 hundreds. Thousands: 3 minus 1 = 2 thousands.' Build answer: 2,215!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we do the other numbers! We have 3 tens and we take away 2 tens, so we have 1 ten left. Then we have 5 hundreds and we take away 3 hundreds, so we have 2 hundreds left. And we have 3 thousands and we take away 1 thousand, so we have 2 thousands left! We made the number 2,215!

slides.prompt: Try: start with 4,631 and take away 2,418. You will need to exchange! Remember: if you do not have enough, go to the next bigger category and exchange.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to try a new number puzzle! Let's start with 4,631 and try to take away 2,418. Remember our special trick: if you don't have enough little beads, go to the next bigger group and trade! You can do it!

slides.text: 'When we do not have enough to take away, we EXCHANGE from the next bigger group — just like in addition! This is called borrowing.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child perform subtraction with exchange in at least one category?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job today! Remember how we didn't have enough little beads and we had to trade a big ten bar for lots of little ones? That's called "borrowing" in math, and it helps us solve tricky subtraction problems. You are a super math whiz!

parent_notes: Subtraction with exchange (borrowing) is the counterpart to addition with exchange (carrying). The child discovers that when there are not enough in a category to subtract from, they can exchange 1 from the next larger category into 10 of the current category. This is the concrete experience behind 'borrowing' in the standard algorithm. The golden beads make the exchange physically visible: the child literally trades 1 ten bar for 10 unit beads. Some children initially resist breaking a ten bar apart, but once they see that 10 units IS the same as 1 ten, the exchange becomes natural. Choose problems that require exchange in only one category at first. Multiple exchanges (borrowing across several columns) can come with more practice.

title: Simple Machines — The Inclined Plane and Wheel
description: The child explores two more simple machines: the inclined plane (ramp) and the wheel and axle. Through hands-on experimentation, the child discovers how these machines make work easier in everyday life.
instructions:
1. Review the lever from last week. 'Today we meet TWO more simple machines!'
2. INCLINED PLANE (ramp): set up a board leaning on a stack of books.
3. 'Try lifting this heavy toy car straight UP to the top. Hard! Now roll it UP THE RAMP. Easier!'
4. 'A ramp spreads the work over a longer distance, making it feel lighter.'
5. WHEEL AND AXLE: show a toy car's wheels. 'Without wheels, we would have to DRAG everything!'
6. Compare: push a book across the table (friction) vs. rolling it on pencils (wheels).
7. Find ramps and wheels in the house: stairs, doorknobs, rolling carts.
materials_needed: Toy car or heavy small object
Pictures of ramps and wheels in real life

slides.heading: Simple Machines
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun slide! It has big words that tell us what we're going to learn about: ramps and wheels. Aren't they cool?

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a ramp with the board and books. Have a heavy small object to lift and roll. Line up pencils for the rolling experiment.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have so many fun things to play with for our activity! We have a long board and some books to build a ramp, a toy car to push, and some pencils to roll. We also have pictures to look at!

slides.text: 'We learned about levers. Today we meet TWO more simple machines! First: the INCLINED PLANE — we call it a RAMP.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we learned about levers last week? Well, today we get to meet two more special helpers that make work easier. Our first new friend is called an inclined plane, but we can just call it a ramp!

slides.text: Set up the ramp. 'Try lifting this toy car straight UP to the top of the books. Hard work! Now... push it up the RAMP.' Child does both. 'Which was easier?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's try something! First, try to pick up this toy car and lift it straight up to the top of the books. Oof, that's hard, right? Now, let's try pushing it up the ramp we built. See how much easier that is?

slides.text: 'The ramp is longer than lifting straight up, but it makes the job EASIER! This is why we use ramps for wheelchairs, moving trucks, and skateboard parks.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't that neat? Even though the ramp is longer, it makes it so much easier to move things up high. That's why we see ramps everywhere, like for skateboards or for people in wheelchairs!

slides.text: 'Next: the WHEEL! Try pushing this book across the table — feel the friction? Now put pencils underneath and roll it.' The book glides! 'Wheels reduce friction!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's try something else. Push this book across the table. Feel how it kind of sticks? Now, let's put these pencils underneath and roll it – whoosh! The pencils help the book roll super smoothly because they are like little wheels!

slides.prompt: Experiment: make the ramp steeper and less steep. Which is easier to push up? Then go on a simple machine hunt: find ramps and wheels in your house! How many can you spot?
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's have some fun! We can make our ramp steeper or flatter to see what happens, and then we get to go on a special hunt around the house to find ramps and wheels everywhere! How many can we find together?

slides.text: 'Ramps and wheels make our lives easier every day! You know THREE simple machines now: lever, ramp, and wheel. Scientists call them SIMPLE MACHINES.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain how a ramp and a wheel make work easier, and find examples in the environment?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job today! We learned that ramps and wheels are like magic helpers that make hard jobs easy. Now you know about three simple machines: levers, ramps, and wheels! You're becoming a super scientist!

parent_notes: Simple machines are everywhere, and once children learn to identify them, they see them constantly — which is exactly the point. The inclined plane experiment is particularly vivid: lifting an object straight up requires more force than pushing it up a ramp (though the ramp requires more distance). The trade-off between force and distance is the key principle of all simple machines. The wheel demonstration with pencils under a book clearly shows friction reduction. After this lesson, go on a simple machine scavenger hunt: stairs are inclined planes, doorknobs are wheel-and-axle mechanisms, scissors are levers, screws are inclined planes wrapped around a shaft. The world becomes a physics laboratory!

title: Printmaking — Leaf Prints
description: The child creates prints using real leaves as stamps. By painting the textured side of a leaf and pressing it onto paper, the child discovers the beauty of natural patterns and the art technique of printmaking.
instructions:
1. Collect 3-5 leaves with prominent veins (maple, oak, fern fronds work well).
2. 'The back of a leaf has raised VEINS. We are going to use these as a stamp!'
3. Demonstrate: paint the veined (back) side of a leaf with a thin, even layer of paint.
4. Press the leaf paint-side down onto paper. Press firmly and evenly. Peel off carefully.
5. 'Look at the beautiful print! You can see every vein!'
6. Create a composition: overlap leaves, use different colors, make patterns.

slides.heading: Printmaking
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to make super cool art today using leaves from outside! We'll learn how to make "prints," which is like making a picture with a stamp.

slides.setup_instructions: Cover the table. Choose leaves with clear veins. Have paint in small amounts on a plate or palette.
slides.mascot_explanation: To make our leaf art, we need a few things! We need some pretty leaves from outside, some colorful paint, a brush to paint with, and some thick paper to make our prints on. We also need newspaper to keep our table clean, and your grown-up can help you find all these things!

slides.text: 'Today we are going to use REAL LEAVES to make art prints! Feel the back of this leaf — can you feel the raised lines? Those are VEINS that carried water through the leaf.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this leaf? Let's feel the back of it together. Can you feel those bumpy lines? Those are called veins, and they helped the leaf drink water when it was growing. Today, we're going to use those bumpy veins to make our art!

slides.text: Demonstrate: 'Paint a thin, even layer on the veiny side. Not too thick or the veins will fill in!' Show even brushstrokes.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we're going to paint the bumpy side of the leaf, the side with the veins. Let's use our brush to put a thin, smooth layer of paint on it, like spreading frosting on a cookie. We don't want too much paint, or we won't see the pretty lines.

slides.text: 'Now carefully flip the leaf over and press it on the paper. Press every part — use your fingers to push down gently.' Then peel the leaf away slowly.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now for the magic part! We're going to carefully flip the leaf over, paint-side down, and gently press it onto our paper. Let's push down with our fingers all over the leaf so the paint makes a good picture. Then, we'll peel it up super slowly.

slides.text: 'Look at the print! You can see every vein and the leaf's shape perfectly! Try another leaf, or the same one with a different color.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! Look at your beautiful leaf print! You can see all those tiny lines, the veins, just like on the real leaf. Isn't that neat? We can try it again with another leaf or even the same leaf with a different color!

slides.prompt: Make prints with all your leaves! Try different colors, overlap prints, create a pattern or a tree shape. Each leaf makes a unique print — like a fingerprint for trees!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to make lots of leaf prints! You can use different colors of paint and even put the leaves on top of each other to make a fun picture. Maybe you can make a tree with all your leaf prints! You can do it!

slides.text: Let prints dry. 'Printmaking is an ancient art form. You used nature itself as your printing tool! Each leaf is unique, and each print is a work of art.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child apply paint to a leaf and create a clear print showing vein detail?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such an amazing job making art with leaves! You used nature to create your own special pictures, and you can see all the beautiful details from the leaf. Your prints look like magic tree fingerprints!

parent_notes: Leaf printing connects art, science (botany), and the natural world beautifully. The child sees the leaf's structure (veins, shape, edges) in a new way because the print reveals details they might not notice just by looking. Different leaves produce dramatically different prints — compare an oak leaf to a fern frond. The key technique is paint thickness: too much paint fills the veins, too little gives a faint print. Experiment together! This is also a wonderful seasonal activity — fall leaves produce stunning warm-colored prints. The prints make beautiful cards, wrapping paper, or journal covers. Some children become fascinated by leaf identification through this process: 'Which tree does this leaf come from?'

title: Care of Environment Review — Choosing a Job
description: The child reviews all care of environment skills learned in weeks 10-12 (flower arranging, plant watering, sweeping, dusting, window washing, table scrubbing) and chooses one to perform independently as their daily responsibility.
instructions:
1. 'This week you learned so many ways to take care of our space! Let's review them all.'
2. List together: flower arranging, watering plants, sweeping, dusting, window washing, table scrubbing.
3. 'Which jobs do you enjoy most? Which do you feel most confident doing?'
4. 'Choose ONE job that will be YOUR daily or weekly responsibility.'
5. The child performs their chosen job independently while you observe.
6. Create a simple care of environment chart with the child's chosen responsibilities.
materials_needed: Materials for the child's chosen job

slides.heading: Care of Environment
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This is about our special jobs that help keep our home nice and tidy. We are going to pick one job that will be all yours to do!

slides.setup_instructions: Have materials available for all previously taught care of environment activities. The child will choose one to perform.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things! We have pretty flowers, a watering can for plants, a broom for sweeping, a duster, and even things to wash windows and scrub tables. You'll need to ask a grown-up to help you find the things for the job you choose!

slides.text: 'You have learned so many ways to care for our home! Let's list them: flower arranging, plant watering, sweeping, dusting, window washing, table scrubbing.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We've learned so many cool ways to help out! We learned how to make flower pictures, give plants a drink, sweep up crumbs, make things shiny, wash windows, and scrub tables.

slides.text: 'Which ones do you enjoy? Which ones are you really good at? It is important to choose a job you WANT to do, because you will do it regularly.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's think about which jobs you liked the most. Which ones made you feel super happy and good at helping? It's important to pick a job you really want to do!

slides.text: 'Today you will choose your RESPONSIBILITY — a job that is yours. You do not need to be asked; you do it because it needs doing and it is YOUR job.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today, you get to choose your very own special job, your "responsibility." This means you get to decide when to do it, and you don't need anyone to tell you – it's your job to help!

slides.text: 'Let's make a chart! We will write your job and mark each day you complete it.' Create a simple tracking chart together.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's make a special chart for your job! We'll write down what you do, and then we can put a sticker or a check mark every time you do your job. It will show everyone how helpful you are!

slides.prompt: Choose your responsibility and do it NOW — completely on your own, from getting materials to cleaning up. Then decorate your responsibility chart with your name and your job.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to do your job all by yourself! Go pick the things you need, do your job super well, and then clean everything up. Then, we can make your chart look extra special!

slides.text: 'You have a REAL job now — one that matters to our whole family. Taking care of your environment is taking care of yourself and the people you love.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child choose and independently complete a care of environment task from start to finish, including cleanup?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You have a real job now, and that's so important for our home and everyone in it. You are such a great helper, and taking care of things means taking care of us too!

parent_notes: This lesson transforms isolated skills into genuine responsibility. Montessori believed that children NEED meaningful work — not busywork, but real contributions to the household. When a child knows that watering the plants is THEIR job, they develop a sense of purpose and belonging. The responsibility chart provides accountability without nagging. Let the child decorate it and post it prominently. Do NOT redo their work if it is imperfect — this communicates that their contribution is not good enough. Instead, occasionally work alongside them, modeling technique. Rotate responsibilities monthly or quarterly so the child builds a full repertoire of skills. Some children take this very seriously and add additional responsibilities on their own.

title: Reading Longer Phrases and Simple Stories
description: The child reads longer phrases and very simple stories using all known phonics skills: single letter sounds, phonograms (sh, ch, th), and sight words. This is a significant reading milestone — the transition from word and sentence reading to story reading.
instructions:
1. Prepare a simple story on separate strips (one sentence per strip):
   'The red fish swam in the pond.'
   'A big frog sat on a thick log.'
   'The frog said, Splash! and got the fish wet.'
   'The fish was not glad.'
   'Then the frog and the fish had a chat.'
   'Now the fish and the frog are pals.'
2. Child reads each strip in order.
3. Retell: 'What happened in the story?'
4. Illustrate the story.
5. Celebrate: the child just read their first story!
materials_needed: Story sentence strips (handwritten in clear print)

slides.heading: Reading Stories
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! It says "Reading Stories" and "Your First Story!" That means we are going to read a whole story all by ourselves, like a big kid!

slides.setup_instructions: Write the story on separate strips in large, clear print. Use mostly decodable words plus known sight words (the, a, was, said, are).
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these special things we need! We have some papers with sentences on them for our story, and we have paper and colorful crayons to draw a picture later. These will help us tell our story!

slides.text: 'Today is a very special day. You are going to read a STORY — not just words, not just sentences, but a whole STORY with a beginning, middle, and end!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today is super special because we get to read a whole story! It's like a book, but we'll read it one sentence at a time, and you're going to do such a great job!

slides.text: Place the first strip: 'Read this sentence.' The child reads: 'The red fish swam in the pond.' 'Great! Now the next part of the story...'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's read the first part of our story together! See this sentence? You can sound out the words and read it. You are doing so great reading the story!

slides.text: Continue strip by strip. Let the child work through each word. For phonograms (th, sh, ch), they should recognize them now. Sight words may need a reminder.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we'll read the next sentence, and then the next one! You're doing amazing sounding out all the words and remembering the special ones, too. Keep going, you're almost there!

slides.text: After reading all strips: 'You just read a whole STORY! Tell me what happened.' The child retells in their own words — this shows comprehension.
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You read the whole story! Now, can you tell me what happened in the story with the fish and the frog? What was your favorite part?

slides.prompt: Draw a picture of the story — the fish, the frog, the pond, the log. Write a title for your picture. If you want, write a sentence about what might happen NEXT!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to draw a picture of our story! Let's draw the fish, the frog, and the pond. You can even draw what you think happens next in the story!

slides.text: 'You read a STORY from beginning to end! You are a real READER now. There are millions of stories waiting for you — and you have the skills to read them!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read a 6-sentence simple story and retell the main events?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are a super reader now! You read a whole story all by yourself, and that's a HUGE deal! All the stories in the world are waiting for you to read them!

parent_notes: Reading a complete story — however simple — is a transformative milestone. The child shifts from decoding isolated words to following a narrative. This requires holding multiple sentences in memory, tracking cause and effect, and understanding character motivations. The story should be mostly phonetically decodable with just a few sight words (the, a, was, said, are). Write it on strips so each sentence feels manageable. The retelling is crucial: it demonstrates comprehension, not just decoding. If the child can retell the story, they understood it. The illustration adds a creative response. Celebrate this moment — the child has crossed the threshold from 'learning to read' to 'reading.' From here, the path leads to simple phonetic readers, then early chapter books, then the entire world of literature.

title: Golden Beads — Subtraction with Exchange Practice
description: The child practices golden bead subtraction with exchange, building fluency. Multiple problems reinforce the sequence: start with a quantity, check if you have enough to take away, exchange if needed, remove the amount, and find the remainder.
instructions:
1. 'Let's practice subtraction with exchange. Remember: if you do not have enough, exchange from the next bigger group!'
2. Problem 1: 5,432 - 2,218 (exchange needed in units: 2-8, exchange 1 ten→10 units, now 12-8=4)
3. Problem 2: 3,714 - 1,536 (exchange in units: 4-6, AND tens: 0-3 after exchange!)
4. For each problem, child works through systematically.
5. Verify answers together.
6. Child creates their own subtraction problem.

slides.heading: Golden Beads
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! We're going to play a game with special golden beads to practice taking numbers away, and sometimes we have to do a little trading, like in a real store!

slides.setup_instructions: Build the starting number. Have the bead bank ready for exchanges. Choose problems that require exchange in 1-2 categories.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these special things we need for our math game! We have shiny golden beads that show big numbers, and cards with numbers on them, and a big mat to build our number on, and a special tray for the beads we take away. Ask a grown-up to help you find these special tools so we can start our game!

slides.text: 'Subtraction with exchange practice! Remember the steps: can I take away? If yes, do it! If no, EXCHANGE first, then take away.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our super important rule for today! When we take numbers away, first we look to see if we have enough. If we don't have enough, it's okay, we just need to trade one of our bigger number pieces for lots of smaller ones, and *then* we can take them away!

slides.text: Problem 1: 5,432 - 2,218. Build 5,432. 'Start with units: take 8 from 2. Oh! Not enough. Exchange 1 ten for 10 units. Now: 12-8=4!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's try our first problem together! We start with the number 5,432, and we need to take away 2,218. We look at the little ones first – can we take 8 from 2? Nope! So, we trade one of our tens for 10 little ones, and now we have 12, so we can take 8 away and have 4 left! Yay!

slides.text: 'Tens: we had 3, but gave 1 away = 2 tens. Take 1 away: 1 ten left. Hundreds: 4-2=2. Thousands: 5-2=3.' Answer: 3,214.
slides.mascot_explanation: We did the little ones, now let's do the next numbers! We had 3 tens, but we traded one, so now we have 2 tens, and we take 1 away, leaving us with 1 ten. Then we take 2 hundreds away from 4 hundreds, leaving 2 hundreds, and 2 thousands away from 5 thousands, leaving 3 thousands! So our answer is 3,214!

slides.text: Problem 2: 3,714 - 1,536. 'Units: 4-6? Not enough! Exchange from tens. Tens: 1, give 1 away = 0 tens. Now 14-6=8 units. Tens: 0-3? Not enough again!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Here is another fun problem! We start with 3,714 and want to take away 1,536. For the little ones, we need to take 6 from 4, but we don't have enough. So we trade a ten for 10 little ones, and now we have 14, so we can take 6 away and have 8 left! But oh no, now we have 0 tens and need to take away 3!

slides.prompt: Finish problem 2 (exchange from hundreds for tens!). Then make up YOUR own subtraction problem. Choose a big starting number and subtract a smaller one. Can you solve it?
slides.mascot_explanation: We're almost done with our second problem! We need to trade one of our hundreds for 10 tens, and then we can take away the tens we need. After that, we take away the hundreds and thousands. Then, it's YOUR turn to make up a super tricky problem using the beads and number cards, and let's see if you can solve it all by yourself!

slides.text: 'You can do addition AND subtraction with the golden beads — even with exchanges! You are working with numbers in the THOUSANDS. That is incredible!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently perform subtraction with exchange, handling at least one exchange correctly?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are amazing! You learned how to take away numbers, even when you had to trade, and you even worked with super big numbers in the thousands! That is so, so smart, and I'm so proud of how hard you worked!

parent_notes: Subtraction with multiple exchanges is the most complex golden bead operation at this level. When both units AND tens require exchange, the child must work through a chain of exchanges — this is exactly what happens in the standard written algorithm when you borrow across multiple columns. Some children find this cascading exchange confusing at first. If so, break it into explicit steps: (1) Check units — enough? No → exchange from tens. (2) Check tens — enough now? No → exchange from hundreds. (3) Now work through each subtraction. This step-by-step approach builds confidence. Creating their own problems is motivating and develops number sense — the child learns that the starting number must be larger than the number being subtracted.

title: Celebrations — Easter and Nowruz (Spring Celebrations)
description: The child learns about two spring celebrations from different cultures: Easter (Christian tradition) and Nowruz (Persian/Iranian New Year). Both celebrate renewal, new life, and the arrival of spring, showing how different cultures mark the same seasonal change.
instructions:
1. 'Spring is a time of new life! Many cultures around the world celebrate spring. Today we learn about two celebrations.'
2. EASTER: 'In the Christian tradition, Easter celebrates new life and hope. People decorate eggs, which are symbols of new life.'
3. Show pictures of Easter eggs, egg hunts, spring flowers.
4. NOWRUZ: 'In Iran and many other countries, the New Year begins on the first day of spring! It is called Nowruz — NOW-rooz.'
5. Show the Haft-sin table: 7 items starting with 's' that symbolize health, beauty, patience, etc.
6. Compare: both celebrate spring, new beginnings, and family togetherness.
materials_needed: Pictures of Nowruz celebrations and Haft-sin table

slides.heading: Spring Celebrations
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title slide! It says "Spring Celebrations" and tells us we're going to learn about two special days called Easter and Nowruz. We're going to discover how people celebrate when the flowers start to bloom and the sun shines brighter!

slides.setup_instructions: Display pictures of both celebrations. Have the globe ready to locate relevant countries.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we have for our learning adventure! We have pretty pictures of Easter and Nowruz so we can see what they look like. We also have a big globe, like a giant ball with all the countries on it, so we can find where these celebrations happen. If you have a real egg, we can even decorate it!

slides.text: 'When spring comes after winter, people all over the world CELEBRATE! Plants grow, animals are born, and the days get longer. Let's learn about two spring celebrations.'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's so exciting that spring is here! After winter, everything wakes up and gets new and fresh, and people all around the world like to celebrate this happy time. We're going to learn about two special ways people say "Hooray for spring!"

slides.text: 'EASTER is celebrated by Christians around the world. Eggs are a symbol of new life! People decorate eggs, have egg hunts, and celebrate with family.' Show pictures.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is Easter! Many people who follow Jesus celebrate Easter. It's all about new life, just like when baby animals are born. They love to decorate colorful eggs, which are like little surprises of new life, and sometimes they even have fun games finding hidden eggs!

slides.text: 'NOWRUZ means New Day! In Iran and many countries, the New Year starts on the first day of spring!' Find Iran on the globe. 'Families set a special table called Haft-sin with 7 items.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is called Nowruz, and it means "New Day"! In a country called Iran and other places, they start their new year when spring begins. Families get together and put out a special table with seven special things that start with the letter 'S' to wish for good health and happiness in the new year.

slides.text: 'Both celebrations are about SPRING — new life, new beginnings, hope! Different cultures, same beautiful idea.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't it neat how different people celebrate? Even though Easter and Nowruz are different, they both love that spring is here! They both celebrate new beginnings and how families like to be together when the world gets green and pretty again.

slides.prompt: If you have an egg, decorate it to celebrate spring! Draw symbols of new life: flowers, baby animals, sunshine. Or draw a Haft-sin table with 7 special items.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's our turn to be creative! If you have an egg, let's decorate it with fun spring pictures like flowers or sunshine. Or, we can pretend to set up a Nowruz table and draw those special seven items. You can make it super colorful and happy!

slides.text: 'People everywhere celebrate spring — the season of new life. Easter and Nowruz are two beautiful ways different cultures welcome the new season!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name both celebrations, explain what each celebrates, and identify the theme of spring/new life?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We learned that people all over the world celebrate spring and new life. We saw how Easter and Nowruz are special ways to welcome the warmer days. Isn't it wonderful that so many people love spring just like we do?

parent_notes: Comparing celebrations from different cultures around a shared theme (spring/renewal) is a powerful way to build both cultural literacy and appreciation for diversity. The child sees that while customs differ, the human response to seasonal change is universal. Present both celebrations with equal respect and enthusiasm. If your family celebrates Easter, the Nowruz information adds a global perspective. If your family celebrates Nowruz, the Easter information adds breadth. If your family celebrates neither, both are presented as fascinating cultural traditions. The Haft-sin table is particularly interesting: seven items beginning with the letter 's' in Persian, each symbolizing something important (health, beauty, patience, sunrise, love, fertility, medicine). This connects to language concepts!

title: Read-Aloud: Officer Buckle and Gloria by Peggy Rathmann
description: Reading 'Officer Buckle and Gloria' by Peggy Rathmann, a Caldecott Medal winner about a police officer whose safety tips become exciting when his dog Gloria acts them out behind his back.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'Who do you see? What do you think the dog is doing?'
2. Read aloud — the humor comes from what Gloria does behind Officer Buckle's back.
3. Encourage the child to look carefully at the illustrations for Gloria's antics.
4. Discuss: 'Why did people start paying attention? Did Officer Buckle know what Gloria was doing?'
5. Talk about teamwork: 'They were better together, weren't they?'
6. Share a safety tip of your own!
materials_needed: Officer Buckle and Gloria by Peggy Rathmann

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: Officer Buckle and Gloria by Peggy Rathmann
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is the name of the special book we get to read today. It's called "Officer Buckle and Gloria," and it sounds like it will be a fun story!

slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. This is a Caldecott Medal winner!
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we have our special book! See? It's this one right here. We're going to read this story together, and it's a very famous and special book that won a big award!

slides.text: Cover: 'This is Officer Buckle and his dog Gloria. What do you think Gloria is doing behind him?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at the front of our book! We see a police officer named Officer Buckle and his dog, Gloria. What do you think Gloria is doing back there behind him? Maybe she's playing a little trick!

slides.text: Read with a straight, serious voice for Officer Buckle. The humor is in Gloria's physical comedy — point out what she's doing!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to read the story! When Officer Buckle talks, I'll use a serious voice, but watch Gloria in the pictures – she's going to do silly things behind his back! We need to look very closely to see all her funny actions.

slides.text: Discuss: 'Why is this story funny? What happened when Gloria stayed home? Why do they need each other?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This story is so funny because Officer Buckle doesn't know what Gloria is doing! When Gloria stayed home, people didn't listen as much. They needed each other to be super safe and super funny!

slides.prompt: Make up your own safety tip! Draw a poster with a safety rule, just like Officer Buckle's stars send him.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's make our own safety poster, just like Officer Buckle! What's something important we should always do to stay safe? We can draw a picture to show everyone our super-duper safety tip!

slides.text: 'Officer Buckle's best safety tip: Always stick with your buddy! They were a great team.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain why Officer Buckle and Gloria worked better as a team?
slides.mascot_explanation: We finished our story and made our own safety tip! Officer Buckle learned that he and Gloria were a great team, and they were best when they worked together. Remember, always stick with your buddy, just like they did!

parent_notes: This Caldecott winner teaches teamwork, friendship, and the value of partnership. The visual humor (Gloria acting out tips behind Officer Buckle) develops visual literacy. It connects to Montessori grace and courtesy lessons about safety and working together. A wonderful read-aloud that children request again and again.
